newsitem.title: MALI: Mali court rejects opposition poll delay request.
newsitem.headline: Mali court rejects opposition poll delay request.

text.p: Mali's constitutional court on Thursday rejected an opposition request for a delay in Sunday's presidential election.
Court president Abdoulaye Dicko announced the ruling as opposition parties staged an authorised protest march in the capital Bamako.
"The opposition petition is inadmissable," Dicko told a news conference at the court.
The opposition had called for the poll to be delayed after severe organisational problems marred an April 13 parliamentary election. The court has scrapped those results.
It had argued that a one-week delay announced by President Alpha Oumar Konare could create confusion. The court did not accept this argument.
Mali, praised for its 1992 democratic transition, has run into trouble with this year's second multi-party national elections.
Malians turned out in force on April 13 only to find that problems with voter cards, lists or ballot materials prevented them from voting.
The main opposition parties have said they will boycott the presidential poll leaving Konare, a historian, with just one challenger -- businessman Hamadou Maribatrou Diaby.
The government has closed schools and colleges after they threw stones and burned Konare campaign posters on Monday.
The presidential poll is the impoverished West African country's second since independence from France in 1960 and seen as a key test of democracy.

Representatives of 15 non-political interest groups, among them the main Islamic body, unions and the business association, condemned both government and opposition politicians for failing to reach an agreement on holding the election.

Political analysts in Bamako compare a wave of student demonstrations, power and water strikes with the tension which gripped the city before the 1991 overthrow of former one-party ruler General Moussa Traore by the military.
Konare, a historian elected in 1992, has steered the country on a course of economic liberalisation. He has won praise from the World Bank and the United States for his efforts.
